ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: clear writing, analyzing texts and close readings
I was exposed to a wide array of some of the greatest works of modern literature, and along the way, I practiced writing essays examining certain features of those works.
Knowledge of literature.

This course provided me with a tremendously insightful vision of the works studied this semester. It taught me how to engage critically with the texts at a profound level and avoid falling into superficial discussions.

This course was great for improving my analytical writing skills, my close reading of literature, and my ability to read and synthesize texts. I also loved the books we read and they give an incredible overview of the western literary canon.
Analysis of literature during more modern times as well as writing and discussion skills
An incredible foundation in the western cannon for literature that will enrich the rest of my reading life
Close reading, meaningfully contributing to class discussions, and greatly improving my writing abilities.
I gained familiarity with key works of western literature, improved the quality and clarity of my writing, and learned how to contribute more meaningfully and concisely to class discussions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: the course was great, incredibly engaging and the lectures were consistently clear, informative and interesting

Spring DS literature definitely has a good selection of works: while you (of course!) want to spend more time on just about all of them, it's a good mix of works that hits a lot of the big ones. Prof. Valis was also clearly deeply excited to be teaching this class and these texts, which is always a benefit. For me, the biggest weakness was the feedback we received on our papers - it was far less comprehensive than any of my other 5 DS classes last semester and this semester, which both didn't help me become a better writer and frequently left me wondering why I had received a certain grade (either positive or negative).
We moved very quickly through authors, but that's the nature of DS.

I believe that a strength of this course was how engaging it was. Specifically, how the students are prompted into discussing some of the major questions regarding the work they are studying and collecting each others' ideas to help their own understanding.

I thought the discussions had an incredibly open and welcoming environment! The class culture was the greatest strength. I suppose discussions could have been a little more guided/focused on occasion just so we could cover more thematic ground given the limited time with each text.

The syllabus and discussion formats were great! I loved almost all of the texts this semester and would gladly revisit them. That being said, perhaps the faculty could cut out some of the less pertinent texts since we already move so quickly and are unable to discuss most of what we are assigned to read.
More poetry!

Strengths: Fantastic texts, available instructor, and constructive discussions/lectures

Weaknesses: A lot of reading, which takes away from the significance of individual texts when only a day or two are spent discussing them

Strengths: well-directed discussions, important and interesting texts, good thematic development in the curriculum and in the choice of texts

Weaknesses: N/A

Most of the books on the syllabus are really enjoyable to read. The problem is that there's just so much reading that it's hard to find time to really appreciate them because you so often have to either skip parts of the reading or speed-read.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
yes it was a really great introductory survey to global literature and really pushed me to improve my writing

Yes, absolutely. DS is definitely a lot, but it is well worth it by the end. Although I personally enjoyed the fall semester of DS literature more than the spring semester, I think that's largely just because I love ancient literature, and the spring semester is well worth it after having done the fall semester. Prof. Valis is a perfectly decent instructor to guide you through the texts we read.
If you want to do DS, then yes.

I would highly recommend Directed Studies literature to any incoming Yale Student! Under this course, I was able to interact with some texts on a level that I never thought I would be able to, and the seminar format definitely helped with my ability to do so.
Yes! Anyone with an interest in literature, humanities, or reading/writing would love this course and find it very valuable.
Yes - its a great continuation of the first semester and I loved the syllabus!
Definitely! A great foundation, and especially with someone as engaging as professor Valis
As long as you are willing to put in the time and effort, this class is worth it. DS as a whole is a significant commitment for which you have to be all-in.

Absolutely I gained a familiarity with important works and ideas that broadened my perspective and that I think will inform my engagement with literature for the rest of my life. Id absolutely recommend it to others.
Compared to the first semester, the readings are even larger, so keep that in mind. However, at least for me, the readings were much more enjoyable.
